inspectionSteps: Open the vehicle’s hood.
Locate and inspect battery terminal.
Inspect for corrosion, rust, cracks and damage.

problemList.title: Bad Starter
inspectionSteps: Open the vehicle’s hood and locate the starter. If it is easier to see and touch the starter from the bottom, you will need to secure your vehicle on jack stands to inspect the starter’s condition.

Ask an assistant to attempt to start the vehicle (hopefully in this case you are now hearing the spinning noise and the vehicle not starting). While you are under the vehicle, knock the rubber mallet hammer on the starter housing.

childWebPageList.title: If you know what is wrong, start by selecting it:
What problem are you having with your brakes?

problemList.title: Worn Front Brakes
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.
Remove the front wheel hub caps if necessary. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, loosen the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift the front of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the front wheels.

After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.
Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

problemList.title: Worn Rear Brakes
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the front wheels.
Remove the rear wheel hub caps if applicable. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, break loose the rear wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift up the rear of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the rear wheels.

If applicable, remove the brake drum retaining clips or screws. Make sure the parking brake is released and mark the drums for installation reference. Remove the brake drums from the hubs or axle flanges.
Clean the brake shoes and drums with a water-based solution. Inspect the inside of the drum for grooves, scoring, and heat discoloration.
Measure the inside diameter of the drum, at two locations, with a drum micrometer. The measurements should be equal and below the maximum diameter stamped on the drum.

Next, carefully inspect the brake shoe linings for wear, heat cracks and fluid contamination. The condition of the linings can often reveal a problem with the brake drums, wheel cylinders, and axle seals.
Inspect the brake hardware for damage. Check the wheel cylinders for leaking brake fluid.

problemList.title: Brake Pad Wear Indicator is Contacting Rotor
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.
Remove the front wheel hub caps if necessary. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, loosen the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift the front of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the front wheels.

After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.
Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

problemList.title: Brake Pad Quality and Rotor Finish
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.
Remove the front wheel hub caps if necessary. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, loosen the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift the front of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the front wheels.

After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.
Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

problemList.title: Worn Brake Pads
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.
Remove the front wheel hub caps if necessary. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, loosen the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift the front of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the front wheels.

After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.
Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

problemList.title: Contaminated Brake Linings
inspectionSteps: Secure your vehicle on a level surface, making sure your car will not roll or lean when jacked up.
Remove the front wheel hub caps if applicable. Using a tire iron, break loose the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Using a floor jack, lift up the front of your vehicle.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the front wheel lug nuts. Remove the front wheels and set them aside.
Repeat steps 2 through 4 to remove the rear wheels.
Inspect the brake caliper for any signs of binding. Look for dirt built up on the caliper slides or lack of lubricant.
For drum brakes, remove the brake drum to gain access to the wheel cylinder. Inspect wheel cylinder for fluid leaks or torn cup seals.

problemList.title: Uneven Tire Pressure
inspectionSteps: Locate the tire’s valve stem and remove the valve stem cap.
Using a tire pressure gauge, hold the gauge down on the valve stem to get the tire pressure reading. Perform this step for all tires on the vehicle.

Compare the tire pressure reading you just got to the recommended tire pressure. This is located on the side wall of the tire. The tire pressure is measured in PSI or pounds per square inch. Look for the letters PSI on the tire. Owners manuals also give the tire pressure for the factory installed tires. Some manufacturers also put it on the manufacturers label located in the door jam of the drivers door, it gives the original factory wheel size, tire sizes, tire ratings, and tire pressure.

problemList.title: Binding Brake Caliper
inspectionSteps: Secure the vehicle on a level surface, making sure the vehicle will not roll or lean when jacked up.
Use a floor jack to lift the vehicle.
Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the front wheels by loosening the lug nuts.
Visually inspect the brake caliper for any signs of binding. Check for dirt built up on the caliper, also inspect for lack of lubrication
Check for uneven brake wear; a binding caliper will cause the brake pads to wear out sooner on one side.
Check for brake fluid leaks around the caliper housing as well as on the inside edges close to the piston(s).

There is a rubber seal that is installed around the inside edge of the caliper piston. Check the rubber seal for leaks, tears and condition. This seal is responsible for much of the caliper function and can cause binding if found to be damaged.
If no leaks or seal damage is found, it will be necessary to replace the faulty brake caliper.

problemList.title: Loose or Worn Suspension Parts
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the top of the suspension strut mounts/shock towers.
Before starting any repairs, be sure  the vehicle is in park.  Have an assistant push down on the fender to simulate driving over bumps.
Locate and Inspect the upper shock mounts on the inside of the engine compartment and underneath the wheel well for damage.
Close the hood, then secure the vehicle on a level surface, making sure it  will not roll or lean when jacked up.
Inspect the vehicle ride height (coil springs, struts, or torsion bars). Some owner’s manuals will have ride height specifications.  The left and right side measurements should be equal.
Using a floor jack, lift the front of the vehicle.
Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle.
Inspect all suspension grease boots for damage and make sure the boots are full of grease.
Use a grease gun and apply grease through the zerk fitting (grease fitting). When the grease begins to ooze from the joint, the boot is full.
Inspect sway bar mounts and end linkage for loose, bent, or missing components. Any damaged linkage will need to be replaced.
Inspect the control arms for damage to the bushings and ball joints. Bushing kits and ball joints are available for replacement; however, replacing the control arm assembly may also be an option.
Inspect the steering rack, steering box, steering column, and the inner tie rod linkage.

Inspect the outer tie rod ends for excessive play at the connection to the steering knuckle. You will also want to inspect the tie rod boots for damage. Note: On some vehicles, it may be necessary to remove the wheels to see and inspect the outer tie rod end.
Replace the necessary suspension system components and take the vehicle to a certified technician for proper alignment.
Test drive the vehicle and verify if there is suspension noise.

aidPair.key: I have a hard brake pedal.

problemList.title: Brake Booster Failure
inspectionSteps: With the engine off, relieve the brake booster of all vacuum by pumping the brake pedal several times.

With the brake pedal depressed, start the engine. The brake pedal should sink slightly when the engine starts. If the pedal does not sink, the brake booster has failed or it is not receiving vacuum from the engine.
Open the hood and locate the brake booster, mounted to the firewall, on the driver side of the engine compartment.

Check for vacuum at the brake booster by pulling the check valve and hose from the booster. Cover the check valve opening with your thumb. If the vacuum is strong, the brake booster will need to be replaced. If the vacuum is weak, inspect the hose and the check valve.

problemList.title: Vacuum leaks
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vacuum hoses. Some Vehicles are equipped with a vacuum hose diagram that can be found under the hood, if not a repair manual is the best way to find were all the vacuum hoses are located for your vehicle. Vacuum hoses are rubber hoses or plastic tubes that operate and control systems such as, emissions,  power brakes, and cruise control. Vacuum leaks can also cause idling and drivability problems.
It may be necessary to use a flashlight in order inspect possible damaged vacuum hoses. Check the vacuum hose that leads to the brake booster for damage or if it is loose.
Continue to inspect for cracked or broken vacuum hoses throughout the engine compartment. Look for worn or disconnected hoses or tubes.

Use a can of carburetor cleaner to spray suspecting hoses. With the vehicle running, spray the hose. If the hose has a leak it will pull the carburetor cleaner in and stabilize the idle for a brief time. If changes are heard after spraying the vacuum hose, it is necessary to replace that particular hose.

aidPair.key: I have a spongy or low brake pedal.

problemList.title: Air in Brake Hydraulic System
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the brake master cylinder reservoir on the drivers side next to the firewall.

Check the brake fluid levels inside the reservoir. Most brake fluid reservoirs are clear and have a "Min" and "Max" indicator stamped on the side. Always make sure the level is between the indicators.
Clean the top of the reservoir and remove the cap. Inspect the color of the brake fluid. If the color is dark, the fluid may be contaminated. Bleeding the brakes is recommended.
If the level is below the MIn mark and the fluid is still clear, add the manufacturer's recommended type of brake fluid. DOT 3 is the most common.

To check for air in the fluid, place the cap on the reservoir and have an assistant pump the brake pedal several times to pressure the system. Remove the the cap and have the assistant release the pedal. If air is in the system, it will cause the brake fluid to squirt back into the reservoir.
Inspect the reservoir cap and seal for damaged.

problemList.title: Brake Master Cylinder Internal Leak.
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the brake master cylinder.
After locating the brake master cylinder, remove the fluid reservoir cap and inspect the brake fluid level.
If the brake fluid level is within specification, re-install the cap. Inspect and make sure the reservoir cap does not leak. If it is suspected of leaking, replace the cap.
Step on the brake pedal, and check if the brake pedal gradually sinks all the way down to the floor. If it does, it will be necessary to replace the master cylinder.

Perform a complete visual inspection of the brake master cylinder. Check all attached brake line fittings and directly behind the assembly for fluid leaks. If leaks are suspected, replace the master cylinder.

problemList.title: Brakes not Adjusted
inspectionSteps: Locate the parking brake lever. It can be foot or hand operated.
Park the vehicle on a slight incline and set the parking brake lever fully.
Place the vehicle in neutral. If the vehicle creeps or rolls, the brake shoes or parking brake cable needs to be adjusted. The brake shoes must be adjusted before the parking brake cable.
Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface. Check the parking brake linkage and equalizer for worn parts. Check the movement and condition of the cables.
Lift up the rear of the vehicle and support it with jack stands. To locate the star wheel adjusters, remove the rubber grommets on the brake drum backing plates.
Try to move the adjuster with a flat head screw driver. If the adjuster does not move, the rear brakes will need to be inspected and the adjuster repaired.

aidPair.key: I have a pulsating brake pedal.

problemList.title: Warped Brake Rotors
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the rear wheels.
Remove the front wheel hub caps if necessary. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, loosen the front wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift the front of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the front wheels.

After the wheels have been removed, inspect the brake rotors for scoring, grooves, and heat discoloration. Check the brake rotor thickness with a micrometer and the lateral run-out with a dial indicator. The brake rotor must meet the manufacturer's specifications.

Inspect the brake pad thickness (1/8 inch minimum) and spin the rotor to check the wear indicator. If you hear a squealing sound, the indicator is contacting the rotor and the pads need replacing. If the pad thickness is okay, remove the calipers and inspect the pad surface for glazing and cracks.
Inspect the brake calipers for binding, corrosion, and missing or damaged anti-rattle clips or shims. Inspect for brake fluid leaks at the calipers and brake hoses.

problemList.title: Out-of-Round Brake Drums
inspectionSteps: Park the vehicle on a solid, level surface and chock the front wheels.
Remove the rear wheel hub caps if applicable. Using a tire iron or lug nut wrench, break loose the rear wheel lug nuts but do not remove.
Lift up the rear of the vehicle with a floor jack.

Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. The pinch welds or the frame rails are the two best locations. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Remove the lug nuts. Remove the rear wheels.

If applicable, remove the brake drum retaining clips or screws. Make sure the parking brake is released and mark the drums for installation reference. Remove the brake drums from the hubs or axle flanges.
Clean the brake shoes and drums with a water-based solution. Inspect the inside of the drum for grooves, scoring, and heat discoloration.
Measure the inside diameter of the drum, at two locations, with a drum micrometer. The measurements should be equal and below the maximum diameter stamped on the drum.

Next, carefully inspect the brake shoe linings for wear, heat cracks and fluid contamination. The condition of the linings can often reveal a problem with the brake drums, wheel cylinders, and axle seals.
Inspect the brake hardware for damage. Check the wheel cylinders for leaking brake fluid.

problemList.title: Loose or Worn Wheel Bearing
inspectionSteps: Secure the vehicle on a level surface.
Jack up the vehicle. Every vehicle comes equipped with a jack from the factory. To locate and properly use this jack, see the vehicle owner’s manual.
Secure the vehicle with jack stands on both sides for safety before starting any work. Do not rely on the jack to hold the vehicle up while working.
Spin the tire assembly and listen for any grinding and rumbling noises. A normal wheel bearing should sound uniform as it spins.

Next, grab the tire at the twelve o'clock and six o'clock position. Try and wobble the tire and wheel back and forth. There should be very little play when doing this. If there is too much play, the wheel bearings could be worn or out of adjustment.

aidPair.key: My brake warning light is on.

problemList.title: Low Brake Fluid
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the brake master cylinder reservoir on the driver side firewall.
If the reservoir is clear, check the brake fluid level.
If the reservoir is not clear, clean the reservoir with a shop towel and remove the cap to inspect the brake fluid level.

problemList.title: Parking Brake Lever Engaged
inspectionSteps: Locate the parking brake lever under the dash or on the center console.
Release the parking brake lever to verify that it was not engaged. Sometimes the lever may not be fully released.

problemList.title: Faulty Parking Brake Switch
inspectionSteps: Locate the parking brake lever under the dash or on the center console. Make sure the lever is fully released.
Remove the center console if applicable.
Locate the parking brake switch next to the lever. Verify that the lever is contacting the switch.
Disconnect the electrical connector to the switch and turn on the ignition. If the warning light is not on, then the switch is faulty.

problemList.title: ABS System Fault
inspectionSteps: Locate your vehicles OBD connection.
Plug your scan tool into the OBD connection with the key in the ON position.

Gather all trouble codes and refer to a vehicle specific service manual for a trouble code index that directs you to the specific component. Refer to our diagnostic trouble coded chart to help you determine your code.

childWebPageList.title: Which warning light is on?

problemList.title: Check Engine Light (Fault Codes)
inspectionSteps: Verify that the check engine light is on while the vehicle is running.
Turn off the engine and locate the data link connector (DLC). For OBD-2, the 16 pin DLC is usually found underneath the driver's side dash, either on the left or right side of the steering column.
Plug the code reader/diagnostic scan tool into the DLC and turn on the ignition. Do not start the engine.
Write down all the diagnostic trouble codes (DTC) displayed on the screen. A definition of the trouble code may be displayed depending on the code reader.

problemList.title: Faulty Alternator
inspectionSteps: With the engine off, open the hood and locate the alternator on the front of the engine.Make sure the alternator belt is on the pulley and the belt is not loose.
Check the battery cables for looseness and corrosion. Clean and tighten the cables if necessary.
Using your digital multi-meter, check the battery voltage. A fully charged battery should have about 12.6 volts. If the voltage is low, check the battery's condition.
To verify that the battery is still good, charge the battery and perform a load test.

After verifying a good battery, start the engine and check the battery voltage. The voltage should rise to 13.5-15 volts. If the voltage reading is less than 13 volts or more than 15.5 volts, the charging system is not functioning correctly.

problemList.title: Serpentine belt slipping/damaged
inspectionSteps: Open the vehicle’s hood and locate the vehicle’s serpentine belt.
Inspect the ribs on the serpentine belt. Check for cracks in the rubber, fraying, or chips to the belt. Look for signs of fluids that may have spilled on the belt.

Check the belt tension by pushing down in the middle of a section of the belt. It should not move more than a half inch. Look at the smooth side of the belt if it looks glazed, like it has a shine to it, the belt is probably loose and slipping on the pulleys.

problemList.title: Low Engine Oil
inspectionSteps: Start your vehicle and warm up the engine oil. Park the vehicle on a level surface and turn the engine off. Turn the engine off and wait 2 or 3 minutes to allow the oil to drain to the bottom of the oil pan.
Open your hood and locate the vehicle’s engine oil dip stick. It is usually located on the drivers side of the engine.
Pull the dipstick out and wipe the engine oil off with a shop rag.
Re-install the oil dipstick into the dipstick tube until it is fully seated.
Pull the oil dipstick out and check the oil level. The oil level should be between the "min" and "max" marks on the dipstick.

problemList.title: Faulty oil pressure sensor
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the oil pressure sensor.
Start the engine and observe the oil pressure gauge.
If the oil pressure gauge reads L or below, disconnect the oil pressure sensor wiring harness and jump the lead to an engine ground.
While the harness is jumped to the negative ground, observe the oil gauge on the dash.

problemList.title: Worn oil pump
inspectionSteps: Open the hood.
Locate the vehicle’s oil pressure sensor. Check the vehicle service manual to find out the oil pressure specifications.
Remove the oil pressure sensor and attach an oil pressure gauge.
Run the vehicle and monitor the gauge for oil pressure. If the pressure is low there could be a problem with the  oil pump.

aidPair.key: Check Engine Light on with code P0382 or, P0400-P0408

problemList.title: Check Engine Light On (EGR Valve)
inspectionSteps: Refer to your vehicle’s owner’s manual for the specific location of your OBDI or OBDII connection.
Turn your key to the “ON” position so that the scanner can receive the code(s).
Plug your scan tool into the OBD connection, turn on the scan tool and select the appropriate steps to read the code. P-codes between P0400-P0408 are generic trouble codes for the EGR system.
To test the EGR valve, remove the vacuum hose from the EGR and apply vacuum manually. You are looking for a drop in the idle, most engines will stall if you fully open the EGR valve while idling.

childWebPageList.title: Which electrical accessory are you having a problem with?
What problem are you having with your power windows?

aidPair.key: One window is not going up or down

childWebPageList.title: When you push the window switch up or down can you hear the window motor inside the door?

problemList.title: Faulty Window Motor
inspectionSteps: The power window motor is located inside the door of the vehicle, in order to completely test the window motor the door panel will need to be removed.

In some cases you will want to check for power at the window switch before you begin taking the entire door panel off. The window switch is either held on with a screw or bolt or is clipped down and can be worked free with a screw driver. there should be enough wire to pull the door away from the switch. Using a test light check for power at the switch. Then check for power at the wires going to the motor. There should be power to one wire when the switch is pushed up and the other when the switch is pushed down.

Door panels are attached differently based on the manufacturer. For the most part the arm rest will be screwed or bolted to the frame of the door and the rest of the panel is usally held on with push pins or clips. The use of a trim panel tool will help to make sure you don't ruin the panel.

Once the panel is off you will have to pull back the piece of plastic that is covering the door. Locate the window motor, disconnect the wire connector, using your test light check for power at the connector coming from the window switch, not the wires coming from the window motor. Now with the test light touching the pin toggle the window switch up and down to check for power going to the motor.

If you found there was power going to the motor from the switch, then there is most likely an internal malfunction in the motor. If the motor is moving or making noises but the window is not moving then you will want to remove the motor and inspect it and the window regulator for broken components.

problemList.title: Faulty Window Regulator
inspectionSteps: The window regulator is located inside the door of the vehicle, in order to completely check the window regulator the door panel will need to be removed.

Door panels are attached differently based on the manufacturer. For the most part the arm rest will be screwed or bolted to the frame of the door and the rest of the panel is usally held on with push pins or clips. The use of a trim panel tool will help to make sure you don't ruin the panel.

Once the panel is off you will have to pull back the piece of plastic that is covering the door. Locate the window regulator, If you had to disconnect the window switch to take off the door panel you will want to reconnect the switch in order to check the regulator.

Using the switch operate the window in both directions, keep an eye on the moving parts of the window regulator. You will want to watch the the arms or pulleys of the regulator and the parts that connect the regulator to the glass. Take note of any problem if any piece is broken you will need to replace the window regulator.

problemList.title: Faulty Window Motor
inspectionSteps: The power window motor is located inside the door of the vehicle, in order to completely test the window motor the door panel will need to be removed.

Now with the test light touching the pin toggle the window switch up and down to check for power going to the motor.

If you found there was power going to the motor from the switch, then there is most likely an internal malfunction in the motor. If the motor is moving or making noises but the window is not moving then you will want to remove the motor and inspect it and the window regulator for broken components.

problemList.title: Bad Power Window Switch
inspectionSteps: Locate the power window switch you will be checking.

Remove the switch from the door panel. Depending on the manufacturer the switch could be screwed on, held on with a clip, or the entire door panel may need to be removed in order to gain access to the back of the switch, where you will be checking the wires.

Using a test light you will want to check the switch for power. Using a wiring diagram check the power supply wire to make sure there is power to the switch. Then you will want to toggle the switch up and down and see if there is power going out of the switch. To do this you made need to poke the pointed end of the test light into the wires that are going to the window motor.

Confirming there is power to the switch but not going to the motor will tell you that the switch has broken and is not making a contact, you will want to replace the switch. Sometimes all that needs to be done is a visual inspection if any part of the switch is broken you will want to change it. If the switch appears to be melted or burnt anywhere you will need to replace the switch, and bring your vehicle to a professional to find the root cause of the problem burnt or melted leads and connectors usually means there is a more serious wiring problem.

problemList.title: Blown Fuse
inspectionSteps: The fuse panel can be located in different locations depending on the manufacturer, check the owners manual for exact location. If you can't find the manual, check for the fuse panel  under the dash board on drivers or passangers side, on the side of the dash, in the glove box, or under the hood in the engine compartment.

Check the back side of the fuse panel cover for a diagram of  the fuses. If not use the owners manual it shoud have labels or a diagram of the fuse panel. Pull out the fuse for the circuit you are testing.

Most vehicle use blade type fuses and can be checked by simply looking through the transparent plastic. There is an internal metal strip that melts when it overheats. Check the strip to see if it has melted.

problemList.title: Malfunctioning Power Mirror
inspectionSteps: Inspect the condition of the mirror, if it is damaged then it will need to be replaced, if only the glass is broken you maybe able to replace just the glass. On some makes the mirror glass can be removed, the glass is attached to a plastic frame that is snapped onto the motor that works the angles of the mirror. Some after market manufacturers sell the frame and mirror assembly, otherwise you may need to remove the glass from the frame which can be a more involved process, it is probably easier to replace the entire mirror assembly if that is the case.

Inspect the operation of the power mirror, if the mirror is moving but not in a specific direction then there is a problem with the internal motor operating the direction of the mirror. If only one of the power mirrors is not working then the problem is in the mirror is that not working most likely the motor has failed. If both power mirrors have failed try the fuse.

inspectionSteps: Locate the wiper blades.
Inspect the wiper blades for cracking, wear or stiffness.

childWebPageList.title: What best describes your wiper problem?

aidPair.key: Wipers are only working on certain speeds or not working on intermittent

problemList.title: Bad Windshield Wiper Switch
inspectionSteps: Turn the key to the on position to provide power to all interior accessories.
Locate the wiper switch
Turn the wiper switch to the on position. Take note of the operation of the wipers, do they come on at all?, Do they operate on all speeds?
In order to inspect the switch you will need a volt tester, a wiring diagram for your vehicles wiper circuit and you will need to remove the switch assembly.

Most common the wiper switch is attached to the steering column. There are typically screws under the column holding the plastic pieces together that cover the column and switch. Once you have removed the column cover remove the screws holding the wiper switch to the column.

Once the switch has been removed you will want to check for voltage into the switch as indicated on the wiring diagram. Then you will want to check for power out of the switch by turning the wipers to the on position and checking the wire that sends the power to the motor as indicated on the wiring diagram.

You will want to make sure first that power is being supplied to the switch, then that the power is being sent through the switch to the motor at all the different speeds. If the power is coming into the switch and you are not detecting voltage coming out or not on a specific speed then problem is with the switch.

problemList.title: Bad Windshield Wiper Motor
inspectionSteps: A wiper motor can be located under the hood on the vehicles fire wall in the back of the engine compartment, or it can be located under the cowl which is the body part that that is in between the hood and windshield of the vehicle. If this is the case you will need to remove the wiper arms and the cowl to gain access to the wiper motor.

For this inspection you will need a volt tester, and the vehicles wiper circuit wiring diagram. Once you have found the wiper motor you will want to disconnect the wiring at the connecter, and then turn the windshield wipers on.

Using your voltage tester test the feed pins to the wiper motor, this is the wire that is no longer connected to the wiper motor. Make sure you have power and ground at the connector as indicated by the vehicles wiring diagram.

Because there is power and ground going to the wiper motor from the switch the problem is with the wiper motor and it will need to be replaced. If there is not power going to the motor then you will want to check the wiper switch, fuse and relay, to determine why the wiper motor is not receiving power.

childWebPageList.title: What is the problem with your engine?

problemList.title: Low Coolant Level
inspectionSteps: Open the Vehicles hood and locate the radiator cap and/or coolant reservoir. The radiator will be located at the front of the engine compartment, the cap is a locking type cap you will need to push down and turn counter clockwise to remove it. If there is no cap at the radiator some coolant systems are fillable through the coolant reservoir.

Once you have removed the radiator cap using a flashlight look down into the radiator, you should be able to see the coolant right near the top. If the coolant is low or empty in the radiator you will need to fill it, and further inspect what caused the coolant loss. If you are checking the reservoir perform the same step, checking the coolant reservoir level. Some reservoirs have a noticeable cold and hot labeled line to aid in checking the coolant level.

problemList.title: Faulty Engine Cooling Fan
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s cooling fan or fans. On older vehicles the fan will be driven by the engine and attached to the water pump. New vehicles use electric fans that are controled electronically by the engine computer.

For electric cooling fans, once you have located the fan locate the electrical connector. This is located on the fan housing and you may need a screwdriver to disconnect it. Using the connector end that goes to the fan you will need to jump power to the leads either use jumper wires from the battery or the use of a powered test light. Apply power to the fan the fan should begin to spin, if the fan does not then the fan motor is not functioning and will need to be replaced. If the fan does turn on then the problem is in the electronic fan control system. Repeat the test if the vehicle has two electric cooling fans.

If your vehicle has a clutch cooling fan that is driven by the motor, the most common problem is the clutch assembly no longer works properly and the fan slips, causing it to not produce enough air movement. If the fan clutch has never been replaced the best course of action is to start there.

problemList.title: Stuck Thermostat
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s upper radiator hose. This hose goes from the radiator to the thermostat housing on the top of the engine.

If the vehicle is hot allow it to cool before performing this test, if the vehicle is all ready cool start the vehicle. Using an infrared thermometer check the temperature at the upper and lower radiator hose. If you do not have an infrared thermometer you can use your hands to test the temperature of the hoses, make sure to be careful of the moving parts of the engine. After several minutes the hoses should begin to get hot, take note of the upper radiator hose. This hose should all at once begin to warm up letting you know the thermostat has opened and the hot coolant is going from the engine to the radiator to be cooled. If several minutes pass and the hose does not get hot, check the engine temperature inside the vehicle if it is climbing and beginning to over heat shut the vehicle down, the problem is the thermostat is stuck closed.

problemList.title: Broken/Missing Fan Shroud Assembly
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the fan shroud, it is at the front of the vehicle mounted to the radiator.
Inspect the fan shroud assembly, it should not be loose or damaged if it is it will need to be replaced.

problemList.title: Worn Engine Mounts
inspectionSteps: Start the engine and locate the engine mounts.
Have an assistant in the vehicle, apply the parking brake, press the brake pedal with your left foot, shift the transmission into gear and lightly apply pressure onto the gas pedal.

When torque is applied to the engine while in gear, visually inspect the engine mounts. Look for excessive movement in the engine mounts and listen for a knocking noise when engine torque is released. Engine mounts are designed to absorb vibration during normal engine operation. Worn engine mounts will allow the engine to shift excessively creating vibration and noise.

problemList.title: Engine Vibration (Harmonic Balancer)
inspectionSteps: Open and support your hood.
Locate your harmonic balancer.
Using a flashlight and mirror, inspect the harmonic balancer for signs of wear.

aidPair.key: Engine missfiring, or loss of power

problemList.title: Bad Ignition Component
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s distributor cap.
Loosen the clips that hold the cap to the distributor housing and inspect under the cap for carbon build up.

problemList.title: Worn Distributor
inspectionSteps: Open your vehicle’s hood.
Start your vehicle.
Locate source of the chirping/squealing noise.
Shut off the engine and remove the distributor.
Check the distributor shaft for excessive movement.

childWebPageList.title: What is your engine performance problem?

problemList.title: Faulty fuel filter
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the fuel filter. In vehicles with fuel injection the fuel filter could be located near the tank. To locate the fuel filter follow the fuel line from the tank to the engine until you find the fuel filter.
Inspect the fuel filter to see if it is clogged.
Since the fuel filter case is not see-through, you will need to remove it from the fuel line and drain the fuel from the fuel filter into a container and inspect the condition of the fuel.

problemList.title: Clogged Air Filter
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the air filter.
On most vehicle vehicles the air filter is found inside an enclosed container, which is either secured with clips, nuts or screws. The container is best identified by an air duct hose leading ot it.
Inspect the air filter for debris, dirt, leaves and other objects that are impeding the path of air entering the air filter.
During inspection of the filter, make sure the filter is positioned and re-installed properly.

problemList.title: Check Engine Light
inspectionSteps: Verify that the check engine light is on while the vehicle is running.
Turn off the engine and locate the data link connector (DLC). For OBD-2, the 16 pin DLC is usually found underneath the driver's side dash, either on the left or right side of the steering column.
Plug the code reader/diagnostic scan tool into the DLC and turn on the ignition. Do not start the engine.
Write down all the diagnostic trouble codes (DTC) displayed on the screen. A definition of the trouble code may be displayed depending on the code reader.

problemList.title: Vacuum leaks
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vacuum hoses. Some Vehicles are equipped with a vacuum hose diagram that can be found under the hood, if not a repair manual is the best way to find were all the vacuum hoses are located for your vehicle. Vacuum hoses are rubber hoses or plastic tubes that operate and control systems such as, emissions,  power brakes, and cruise control. Vacuum leaks can also cause idling and drivability problems.
It may be necessary to use a flashlight in order inspect possible damaged vacuum hoses. Check the vacuum hose that leads to the brake booster for damage or if it is loose.
Continue to inspect for cracked or broken vacuum hoses throughout the engine compartment. Look for worn or disconnected hoses or tubes.

Use a can of carburetor cleaner to spray suspecting hoses. With the vehicle running, spray the hose. If the hose has a leak it will pull the carburetor cleaner in and stabilize the idle for a brief time. If changes are heard after spraying the vacuum hose, it is necessary to replace that particular hose.

problemList.title: Check Ignition Coil for Spark
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s ignition coil.
Connect the spark tester to the ignition coil output.
Crank the engine.

Follow a wiring diagram to determine if the coil is power or ground side controlled. If controlled by ground connect the test light clip to power side of battery and touch the test light to the negative side of the coil.
Crank the engine and look for the test light bulb to flash.

problemList.title: Fuel system cleaning
inspectionSteps: To inspect your fuel system, drive your vehicle to see how it performs. Your vehicle should drive smoothly, accelerate with ease, and go up and down through the speed limits easily. The mileage on your vehicle and the condition of the engine will also have an influence on how the vehicle drives.
If you have a clear fuel filter, inspect the color of the fuel. If the fuel is dark, the fuel system needs to be flushed.

Open the fuel fill cap and try to smell the fuel. If the level is low remove the Fuel Filter (see instructions for fuel filter replacing) and smell the fuel. If the fuel smells like varnish, the fuel is bad.

You may also want to inspect the condition of the fuel lines and fuel tank. If you notice that fuel lines are cracked (allowing water/condensation to enter the fuel lines) or that the fuel tank is rusted or has cracks, you will want to replace these parts.

problemList.title: Check Engine Light

problemList.title: Fuel pump replacement
inspectionSteps: Check the fuel cap, fuel tank, and fuel lines for leaks. Repair all leaks before proceeding.
On most late model vehicles, the electric fuel pump is located in the fuel tank. Remove the gas cap so that you can hear the fuel pump start.

Next, have an assistant turn on the ignition while you listen for the hum of the fuel pump. If the pump is working, it will hum for two to three seconds and then shut off when the system is pressurized.

If the pump does not turn on, check the pump fuse to see if it is blown. If the fuse is good, check the pump relay and inertia switch (if applicable). If the relay and switch are good, then check the fuel pump.

Remove the access plate or lower the fuel tank and check for voltage and ground at the fuel pump electrical connector. If the voltage and ground are good (and the pump does not turn on), then the pump is faulty and should be replaced.

problemList.title: Faulty Coil Over Plug
inspectionSteps: Start your vehicle.
Locate your check engine light and monitor its status.
Verify that the check engine light is on while the engine is running.
Connect scanner to the OBD output.
Follow the scanner’s instructions to retrieve diagnostic trouble code(s).

problemList.title: Engine Tune-up
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s air filter, drive belts, distributor cap, spark plugs, and spark plug wires. These are parts that are most commonly replaced during an engine tune up.
Remove the air filter from the air box that it may be held in and check for dirt and debris built up on the air filter.
Check the drive belts for cracking, splitting and signs of old age.
If the vehicle is equipped with a distributor cap and spark plug wires, check the insides of the cap for corrosion, burnt spark terminals, and check the wires for cracking, tearing or burning.

problemList.title: Fouled Spark Plug
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the spark plugs. The spark plugs are found inside the cylinder head assembly located above or on the side of the cylinder head block.
Remove any covers or parts obstructing access to the spark plugs, if necessary.
Leading to each spark plug is a spark plug wire or coil pack. Remove the spark plug wire or coil pack to gain access to the spark plug.
Use the correct size spark plug socket and begin to remove each spark plug. Carefully rotate the spark plug counter-clockwise.
After removing the spark plug, inspect the tips for sign of wear. Inspect for a broken tip, discoloration or contamination.
If there appears to be any sign of wear or damage to the spark plug, replace it.

problemList.title: Check Engine Light On (Idle Control Valve)
inspectionSteps: Refer to your vehicle’s owner’s manual for the specific location of your OBDI or OBDII connection.
Turn your key to the “ON” position so that the scanner can receive the code(s).
Plug your scan tool into the OBD connection, turn on the scan tool, and select the appropriate steps to read the code. P-codes between P0505-P0510 are common codes for idle control valves.
Refer to a vehicle specific repair guide for resistance specifications for your engines idle control valve. If the resistance is out of specifications, the idle control valve or IAC must be replaced.

aidPair.key: Carburetor engine stalling and running rough at low RPM

problemList.title: Bad Carburetor
inspectionSteps: Locate the carburetor and remove the air cleaner assembly to gain full access to the carburetor.
With the engine running at idle, inspect for fuel leaks around the seals of the carburetor.
With the engine still running at idle, adjust the air and fuel mixture screws.
Shut the engine off and inspect the bowl of the carburetor. Signs of carbon build up indicate a rich fuel condition typically caused by internal damage in the carburetor.

problemList.title: Rough Idle (Throttle Body)
inspectionSteps: Open your hood and locate your engine’s throttle body.
Remove the air intake duct at the throttle body.
Inspect the throttle body ports for carbon build up. Throttle bore wear is also common after long periods of time and throttle body assemblies will need to be replaced if worn.

What area is damaged on the front of your vehicle?

aidPair.key: Fascia (Front cover) (also includes absorber, reinforcement, License bracket,side supports, sensors, valance, spoiler)

childWebPageList.title: What part on the front of your vehicle looks damaged?
What type of front bumper do you have?

problemList.title: Damaged Bumper Cover
inspectionSteps: Remove and clean any loose paint or dirt from the bumper’s damaged area.

Visually inspect the damaged area to see how large the dent is. Look for any cracks, creases, or cuts in the plastic.  If dents are too large to fix the bumper cover will need to be replaced. If the dent is through a style line or on a curve, the bumper cover will need to be replaced.

Run your hands over the damaged area to see if you feel any dents or distortions on the bumper cover. Check for any obvious plastic damage before running your hands across the bumper cover. Always wear gloves for inspections, and be careful of sharp edges.
Check the left and right sides of the bumper cover where it mounts to the body to see if it has broken loose.

problemList.title: Damaged Front Bumper
inspectionSteps: Locate the damaged area of the vehicle.

Determine which part or parts of the vehicle are damaged. For example if your drivers side front fender is damaged, then also check for damage at the door either from being pushed into it, or from contact. Clean off any loose paint using a cloth or rag.

Visually inspect the damage, dents can be popped out and will most likely need to be painted. Scratches or scores that go into the metal, can be bondo'd; the process of using a polyester or fiberglass resin to fill a scratch or dent in a metal or plastic body part. However if the damage is excessive or the body part has become warped or distorted from the damage the best course of action is to replace the damaged body part. When it comes to large dents or scratches there is no rule of thumb; when deciding if the body part should be replaced or repaired things to consider are, the cost of the part vs repair of it, and time it would take to repair based on size of damage.

For plastic body parts such as; valances, bumper covers, and spoilers, you will want to check for cracks. If the plastic is cracked then it will need to be replaced, for the most part cracked plastic is not easily repaired and it is best to replace the part.

When the damage is beyond a simple patch and repair, you will need to check all the supports and brackets that hold that body part in place. These will need to be repaired or replaced also in order for the new body part to fit correctly.

problemList.title: Damaged energy absorber
inspectionSteps: In order to see the energy absorber you will need to remove the bumper cover. The bumper cover is either held on with clips, screws or a combination of both. To remove them use a trim panel removal tool and a screw driver. It is best to start on one side and work your way across making sure you get all of the clips and screws.
Pull off the bumper cover to expose the energy absorber. Look for cracks and dents in the energy absorber. If it is damaged or distorted it will need to be replaced.

problemList.title: Damaged bumper reinforcement
inspectionSteps: The bumper cover and energy absorber may need to be removed in order to be able to see the bumper reinforcement.

Open the vehicle hood and locate the bumper reinforcement, or it may be easier to view the reinforcement from under the vehicle.  Visually inspect the reinforcement, if it is damaged it will need to be replaced. The bumper reinforcement holds the energy absorber to the frame, if this is damaged in an accident the reinforcement needs to be replaced so that the new body parts will line up correctly.

childWebPageList.title: What type of license plate bracket do you have?

problemList.title: Damaged metal license plate bracket
inspectionSteps: Inspect the license plate bracket for damage.

problemList.title: Damaged plastic license plate bracket
inspectionSteps: Inspect the license plate bracket for damage.

problemList.title: Damaged Bumper Bracket/Side Support
inspectionSteps: In order to see the bumper brackets you may need to remove the bumper cover. The bumper cover is either held on with clips, screws or a combination of both. To remove them use a trim panel removal tool and a screw driver. It is best to start on one side and work your way across making sure you get all of the clips and screws.
The bumper brackets hold the bumper to the frame. Check both sides for damage, make sure they are not bent at all even a small bend will cause new body parts to not align properly.

Inspect the grille for cracks or damaged mounting tabs.

problemList.title: Damaged Front End Cover

Inspect your front end cover for tears, holes or missing sections that expose the body panels.

aidPair.key: Front Lamps (includes; Headlamps, signal lamps, fog lamps, etc.)

problemList.title: Damaged Headlight Assembly
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the headlight assembly.
Disconnect the electrical connectors from the back of the headlight assembly.
Remove the headlight assembly from the headlight housing by removing the headlight mounting screws or retainer.
Inspect the headlight housing for damage.

problemList.title: Damaged Headlight Door
inspectionSteps: Locate your headlight doors.
Inspect the doors to see if they are damaged or missing.

problemList.title: Damaged Headlight Cover
inspectionSteps: Locate your headlight covers.
Inspect the covers for damage or to determine if they are missing.

problemList.title: Turn Signal Lens Assembly (Damaged)
inspectionSteps: Locate your turn signal light assemblies.
Inspect the turn signal light assemblies for damage.
After inspecting the turn signal light for damage, check for proper operation.

If the tuen signal light appears to be inoperable, there is a good chance that the turn signal bulb has failed. If the turn signal bulb is in good shape, but inoperable, perform further inspection in the bulb connector, fuse, switch and wiring.

problemList.title: Damaged fog light assembly
inspectionSteps: Locate the fog light assembly. The most common location for the foglight assembly is found on opposite sides of the front lower body trim of the vehicle.
Visually inspect the fog light assembly.
If the fog light appears damaged or if it does not turn on, it may be necessary to replace.

problemList.title: Damaged Parking Light Assembly
inspectionSteps: Locate your parking light assemblies.
Inspect the parking light assemblies for damage.
After inspecting the parking light assmebly for damage, check for proper operation.

If the parking light appears to be inoperable, there is a good chance that the parking light bulb has failed. If the parking light bulb is in good shape, but inoperable, perform further inspection in the bulb connector, fuse, switch and wiring.

problemList.title: Damaged Side Marker Light Assembly
inspectionSteps: Locate your side marker light assemblies.
Inspect the side marker light assemblies for damage.
After inspecting the side marker light for damage, check for proper operation.

If the side marker light appears to be inoperable, there is a good chance that the side marker bulb has failed. If the side marker bulb is in good shape, but inoperable, perform further inspection in the bulb connector, fuse, switch and wiring.

problemList.title: Damaged Cornering Light
inspectionSteps: Locate your cornering light assemblies.
Inspect the cornering light assemblies for damage.
Check the wiring leading to the cornering light and use a test light to check for voltage. If voltage checks fine, then proceed to inspect the bulb.
If the bulb appears to be burnt, it will need to be replaced.

aidPair.key: Radiator support ( includes; core support, tie bars, splash shields)

childWebPageList.title: What part on your radiator support is damaged?

problemList.title: Replace radiator support
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the radiator support. The radiator support is the metal bracket or braces that hold the radiator up but the following are also typically mounted to the radiator support: grille, headlights, marker lights, turn signal assemblies, and a/c condenser.

Inspect the radiator support for damage, typically in a front end collision the radiator support may be damaged. You may have to remove the headlights and or grille to get a better look at the support. If the headlights and other front body component pieces have been damaged make sure you check the radiator support. Not changing repairing the radiator support could result in the new parts not fitting correctly.

problemList.title: Damaged Fan Shroud
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the fan shroud, it is at the front of the vehicle mounted to the radiator.
Inspect the fan shroud assembly, it should not be loose or damaged if it is it will need to be replaced.

problemList.title: Damaged Header Panel
inspectionSteps: Locate the damaged area of the vehicle.

Determine which part or parts of the vehicle are damaged. For example if your drivers side front fender is damaged, then also check for damage at the door either from being pushed into it, or from contact. Clean off any loose paint using a cloth or rag.

Visually inspect the damage, dents can be popped out and will most likely need to be painted. Scratches or scores that go into the metal, can be bondo'd; the process of using a polyester or fiberglass resin to fill a scratch or dent in a metal or plastic body part. However if the damage is excessive or the body part has become warped or distorted from the damage the best course of action is to replace the damaged body part. When it comes to large dents or scratches there is no rule of thumb; when deciding if the body part should be replaced or repaired things to consider are, the cost of the part vs repair of it, and time it would take to repair based on size of damage.

For plastic body parts such as; valances, bumper covers, and spoilers, you will want to check for cracks. If the plastic is cracked then it will need to be replaced, for the most part cracked plastic is not easily repaired and it is best to replace the part.

When the damage is beyond a simple patch and repair, you will need to check all the supports and brackets that hold that body part in place. These will need to be repaired or replaced also in order for the new body part to fit correctly.

problemList.title: Damaged hood insulator
inspectionSteps: Open the hood.
Locate the hood insulator on the underside of the hood. Visually inspect for any tears, holes, or deterioration to the insulator.

problemList.title: Damaged Hood lock assembly
inspectionSteps: With the hood closed pull up on the hood and make sure it is locked properly. Check and make sure the hood is lined up correctly all the lines should be even between the hood and grille; and hood and fenders.
Now open the hood by pulling the hood pop located under the dash on the drivers side. Check and make sure the hood has popped.

problemList.title: Damaged hinge
inspectionSteps: With the hood closed check the gaps around the edge of the hood. The gaps should be the same on both sides of the hood.
Open the hood and visually inspect the hinges for any damage. Open the hood and look at the hinges to see if they are hitting any of the cowl trim pieces.
Check to see if the hood fits securely into the latch when closed.

problemList.title: Damaged energy absorber
inspectionSteps: In order to see the energy absorber you will need to remove the bumper cover. The bumper cover is either held on with clips, screws or a combination of both. To remove them use a trim panel removal tool and a screw driver. It is best to start on one side and work your way across making sure you get all of the clips and screws.
Pull off the bumper cover to expose the energy absorber. Look for cracks and dents in the energy absorber. If it is damaged or distorted it will need to be replaced.

problemList.title: Damaged bumper reinforcement
inspectionSteps: The bumper cover and energy absorber may need to be removed in order to be able to see the bumper reinforcement.

Open the vehicle hood and locate the bumper reinforcement, or it may be easier to view the reinforcement from under the vehicle.  Visually inspect the reinforcement, if it is damaged it will need to be replaced. The bumper reinforcement holds the energy absorber to the frame, if this is damaged in an accident the reinforcement needs to be replaced so that the new body parts will line up correctly.

problemList.title: Damaged Tail Light Assembly

Check for any cracks in the tail light assembly

childWebPageList.title: What area is damaged on the right side of your vehicle?
What Part of the fender is damaged?

problemList.title: Damaged fender liner
inspectionSteps: The fender liner is the piece of plastic that is attached to the vehicle body fender and possible frame or another section of the body. Check the fender for damage, if it is hanging or not supported correctly.

problemList.title: Damaged mud flap (mud guard)
inspectionSteps: Locate the mud guards behind the wheels. Check the mud guards for damage, if they are damaged they will need to be replaced.

problemList.title: Damaged Antenna Mast
inspectionSteps: Locate the antenna mast, check the antenna mast for bends, if the antenna mast is broken it will need to be replaced. If it is powered up and down mast and is not functioning the hole unit will need to be replaced.

childWebPageList.title: What part of the front door is damaged?

problemList.title: Damaged Window Belt Strip
inspectionSteps: Locate and inspect the window belt strip. Check it for tears, cracking, the window belt strip can wear over time and can cause water to leak into the inside of the door which can rust the inside of the door and internal door components.

problemList.title: Damaged run channel
inspectionSteps: Visual inspect the window run channel seals, look for damages, such as cracks, also a window run channel should not be loose or falling off the door. The seals should fit securely in the door and be difficult to pull out. If there is a problem with them the window may feel loose or sloppy when it is all the way in the up position.

childWebPageList.title: What part of the rear door is damaged?
What area is damaged on the left side of your vehicle?
What part of the fender is damaged?
What part of the front door is damaged?
What part of the rear door is damaged?

problemList.title: Damaged Soft Top
inspectionSteps: Locate your vehicle’s soft top.

Inspect soft top for damage. Rips and tears can sometimes be repaired with a patch, also rips along threaded areas may be repairable. If the soft top is weathered and brittle it will need to be replaced.

childWebPageList.title: What is the problem with your heat or a/c?

aidPair.key: No cold air when A/C is on

problemList.title: No Cold Air A/C Compressor
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate your vehicle’s A/C compressor. Make sure the engine area has cooled off before inspecting your vehicles belt and A/C compressor to prevent any burns or injury. Use a mirror and a flashlight to inspect hard to access A/C compressors.

Check the A/C compressor clutch and pulley, to do this remove the vehicle serpentine or A/C belt. Once the belt is removed spin the A/C compressor pulley, it should feel uniform when spinning. If you notice any grinding, scrapping or it feels loose then it will need to be repaired. If the pulley checks out ok, reinstall the belt.

Another check you can perform is while the vehicle is running, leave the hood up and start the vehicle. Turn the A/C on inside the vehicle. Next watch and listen to the vehicle while it is running. The A/C clutch will cycle on and off, listen for changes if you hear a squealing when the compressor clutch engages, the A/C compressor clutch could be wearing out. A click followed by a low spinning noise is the normal operation of the compressor.

problemList.title: No Cold Air A/C Line or Hose
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s A/C lines or hoses.
Inspect the A/C lines or hoses for cracks and kinks. Check the hose fittings and mounting bracket locations for wear and leaks.

problemList.title: No Cold Air A/C Condenser
inspectionSteps: Locate your A/C condenser.
Inspect the condenser for cracks that would lead to leaking.

aidPair.key: No hot air when heat is on

problemList.title: Bad Heater Control Valve
inspectionSteps: Start the engine and turn on the heater.
Move the heater temperature switch from cooler to warmer and check for a change in air temperature.
Locate the heater control valve which is typically mounted to the firewall and connected to the heater temperature switch by a cable to regulate the coolant flow through the valve.
Check for leaks to the heater control valve.
Verify that the interior air flow temperature is not warming up.

problemList.title: Clogged Heater Core
inspectionSteps: You will need to start the vehicle and allow the engine to warm up to perform this check.
Once the vehicle is warmed up turn the heat on high temp, and the fan speed on low.
Open the vehicles hood and locate the two heater hoses that are going to the heater core
Now check the temperature of both heater core hoses, you can do this with a laser temperature reader, or you can use your own touch just be careful they can become extremely hot.
Take note of the temperature of both hoses, is one hose significantly hotter than the other?

problemList.title: Bad Thermostat
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the vehicle’s upper radiator hose. This hose goes from the radiator to the thermostat housing on the top of the engine.

If the vehicle is hot allow it to cool before performing this test, if the vehicle is all ready cool start the vehicle. Using an infrared thermometer check the temperature at the upper and lower radiator hose. If you do not have an infrared thermometer you can use your hands to test the temperature of the hoses, make sure to be careful of the moving parts of the engine. After several minutes the hoses should begin to get hot, take note of the upper radiator hose. This hose should all at once begin to warm up letting you know the thermostat has opened and the hot coolant is going from the engine to the radiator to be cooled. If several minutes pass and the hose does not get hot, check the engine temperature inside the vehicle if it is climbing and beginning to over heat shut the vehicle down, the problem is the thermostat is stuck closed.

aidPair.key: No air out of the vents when I turn on the a/c or heat
Windshield fogs up with the defroster setting on

problemList.title: Leaking heater core
inspectionSteps: Open the hood locate and remove the radiator cap
Connect the pressure tester to the radiator filler. Pumping the pressure tester raise the pressure to the rating that is on the radiator cap.

Watch the gauge on the pressure tester it should be able to hold the pressure for 12-15 minutes, if the gauge starts to fall immediately there is a system leak. Visually inspect the vehicle for coolant leaks. Check the radiator, water pump, coolant tank, radiator hoses, and check under the vehicle for drips that you can follow back to the location of the leak. Also check inside the vehicle, the heater core is located inside the dash on the passengers side, check the front passenger floor for dampness, also look under passenger side dash for any signs of a coolant leak.

problemList.title: Blown Fuse
inspectionSteps: The fuse panel can be located in different locations depending on the manufacturer, check the owners manual for exact location. If you can't find the manual, check for the fuse panel  under the dash board on drivers or passangers side, on the side of the dash, in the glove box, or under the hood in the engine compartment.

Check the back side of the fuse panel cover for a diagram of  the fuses. If not use the owners manual it shoud have labels or a diagram of the fuse panel. Pull out the fuse for the circuit you are testing.

Most vehicle use blade type fuses and can be checked by simply looking through the transparent plastic. There is an internal metal strip that melts when it overheats. Check the strip to see if it has melted.

problemList.title: Link Defroster grid
inspectionSteps: Locate the rear defroster grid on the rear window.
Turn the rear defroster on.
Ground the negative cable connector with a DMM (digital multi meter).
Place the positive side of the probe at the center of the grid and check for voltage at each line.

aidPair.key: The fan speeds are not working properly e.g., High works but the other speeds do not.

problemList.title: Blower Resistor Malfunction
inspectionSteps: Turn the ignition key to the run position. It is not necessary to have the vehicle running.
Check the fuse for the blower motor circuit at the fuse panel, it should be labeled HVAC or blower motor.
Check the blower motor relay (not applicable on all vehicles)

Locate the blower motor and resistor. They will be mounted to the blower housing which is located under the passenger side dash or in the passenger side of the engine compartment attached to the fire wall.
Remove the electrical connector at the blower motor, attach a voltmeter to the blower motor connector.
Run the heat or A/C through all of the fan speeds, the voltage should change as you go through the fan speeds. The faster the speed the higher the voltage.

If there is voltage but the blower is not working, you can test the blower motor by using jumper wires. Connect a jumper wire to the motor ground terminal and a good ground and another jumper wire to the positive terminal on the battery and touch it to the positive terminal on the blower motor. If the blower motor spins, there is a chance the circuit has a bad ground. If the Motor does not spin, the blower motor is faulty.

If there is no voltage at all or at certain fan speeds then unplug the connector to the resistor and check the pins for voltage. If there is voltage at the pins then the resistor is faulty. You can also check the resistor by removing it and checking it for continuity across the resistors.

If there is no voltage going to the resitor then remove the heater and A/C control and check for voltage into and out of the control. If there is voltage to the control but not going to the resistor then the control is faulty.

childWebPageList.title: Which lights are you having a problem with?
What best describes the problem with the headlights?

aidPair.key: The headlights are not pointing in the correct direction

problemList.title: Headlight Out of Adjustment
inspectionSteps: Park vehicle on a level grade, facing a wall approximately 25 ft. away from the front of the vehicle.
Measure from the ground to the center of your headlamp lens.
Using the measurement you got from your headlamp height, apply a horizontal strip of tape 4-inches lower, on the wall.
Turn headlights on (low beams).

After the headlights have been turned to the "ON" position, inspect and measure for proper headlight direction and that they are within specification. If not, it will be necessary to perform a headlight adjustment.

problemList.title: Bad Headlight Bulb
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the headlight assembly.
Locate the headlight selector switch found either on the steering column or on the driver's side dashboard console.
Turn the headlight selector switch to the "ON" position and check to see if the headlight bulbs turn on.
If the headlight bulbs do not turn on, proceed with the inspection. It may be necessary to gain access to the headlight bulb assembly  and inspect it for a sufficient power supply.
Gain access to the headlight bulb and remove it to expose the power source wire connector.
After access is gained,  check for power at the power connector using a test light or Digital Volt ohm-meter. Verify that the connector is able to recieve power when the headlight switch is applied.

If power is not recieved, the problem may at the switch, wiring or at the connector which will require further inspection. If the connector does recieve sufficient power, the problem is with the bulb. Replace the bulb.

problemList.title: Bad High Beam Bulb
inspectionSteps: Open the hood and locate the headlight assembly.
Locate the headlight selector switch found either on the steering column or on the driver's side dashboard console.
Turn the headlight selector switch to the "ON" position and check to see if the headlight bulbs turn on.
If the headlight bulbs do not turn on, proceed with the inspection. It may be necessary to gain access to the headlight bulb assembly  and inspect it for a sufficient power supply.
Gain access to the headlight bulb and remove it to expose the power source wire connector.
After access is gained,  check for power at the power connector using a test light or Digital Volt ohm-meter. Verify that the connector is able to recieve power when the headlight switch is applied.

If power is not recieved, the problem may at the switch, wiring or at the connector which will require further inspection. If the connector does recieve sufficient power, the problem is with the bulb. Replace the bulb.

childWebPageList.title: What is the problem you are having with your turn signals?

aidPair.key: Turn signal, is out or is flashing faster than normal

problemList.title: Turn Signal Bulb Out
inspectionSteps: Place the ignition key in the on position.
Activate the turn signal switch.

If one of the turn signal bulbs is out any additional bulbs may flash faster, the turn signal may stay solid and not blink, or the signal may not come on at all. This is a safety mechanism the vehicle is letting you know there is a turn signal bulb malfunction.

Leaving the turn signal on, step outside the vehicle and check to see which bulb is not working. There is at least one turn signal bulb in the front and rear of every vehicle. Some vehicles are equipped with additional signal bulbs on the side or side view mirror of the vehicle.

aidPair.key: None of the turn signals are working

problemList.title: Blown Fuse
inspectionSteps: The fuse panel can be located in different locations depending on the manufacturer, check the owners manual for exact location. If you can't find the manual, check for the fuse panel  under the dash board on drivers or passangers side, on the side of the dash, in the glove box, or under the hood in the engine compartment.

Check the back side of the fuse panel cover for a diagram of  the fuses. If not use the owners manual it shoud have labels or a diagram of the fuse panel. Pull out the fuse for the circuit you are testing.

Most vehicle use blade type fuses and can be checked by simply looking through the transparent plastic. There is an internal metal strip that melts when it overheats. Check the strip to see if it has melted.

problemList.title: Turn Signal Bulb Out
inspectionSteps: Place the ignition key in the on position.
Activate the turn signal switch.

If one of the turn signal bulbs is out any additional bulbs may flash faster, the turn signal may stay solid and not blink, or the signal may not come on at all. This is a safety mechanism the vehicle is letting you know there is a turn signal bulb malfunction.

Leaving the turn signal on, step outside the vehicle and check to see which bulb is not working. There is at least one turn signal bulb in the front and rear of every vehicle. Some vehicles are equipped with additional signal bulbs on the side or side view mirror of the vehicle.

problemList.title: Turn Signal Switch Bad
inspectionSteps: Locate the turn signal switch assembly, which is commonly found on the driver's side steering column.
After locating the turn signal switch, activate the switch by pulling up and down on the lever.
Once the turn signal switch is activated, check and inspect the function. Have an assistant check to see if all turn signal bulbs are flashing while the switch is being activated.
If the turn signal bulbs do not flash after the switch is activated, it will be necessary to perform a further inspection. Check the fuse and wiring leading to the switch.
If the wiring and fuse is fine, proceed to inspect the switch. Replace the switch if it has failed.
